episodes.original_body:
Case: Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023
Client: Timothy Ruhl

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Was able to speak with briefly, client insisted on sending previous attorney file to us via snail mail. asked Faye to send a SASE to him. Don't know many details of incident other than note from messages

Spoke w/Mr Ruhl. he had a previous atty (and he has possession of his case file) - he said the previous atty said that it was a good case - but that he does not possess the staff (only atty and his wife - who is also an attorney) nor the funding for his case expenses to continue..
Mr Ruhl said on Sept 14, 2023 he was physically assaulted in his apartment complex parking lot by a delivery truck driver (he said the truck company is Enterprise -and it was making deliveries on behalf of Menards). He asked the truck driver if he could move his truck - that had his vehicle blocked from moving.- he said the driver called him a racial slur and an asshole and then the truck driver hit Mr Ruhl's parked vehicle. He asked the delivery truck driver for a business card and drivrer was so aggravated - truck driver gets out of the truck and punches him in the face. Mr Ruhl said there was another person in the Enterprise truck passenger side - and this older black man gets out of the truck and comes and picks him up and punches Mr Ruhl in the face and slams him - head first to the ground. (which Mr Ruhl's girlfriend witnessed ) He had lacerations on his head and back pain from injury. He said he has a PR. He also went to the hospital after the incident. Mr Ruhl said he is a smaller, disabled person

sent intake docs via vinesign 
__Person Making Contact:__ Justin
__Date & Time__: July 22 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023. Client: Timothy Ruhl.

Initial client contact on July 22, 2024, with Justin regarding intake for Timothy Ruhl. During the call, Mr. Ruhl stated that he previously had an attorney and currently possesses his case file. The prior attorney told him it was a good case, but he does not have staff beyond the attorney and his wife (who is also an attorney), nor does he have funding to continue with the case expenses.

Mr. Ruhl described an incident that occurred on September 14, 2023, in the parking lot of his apartment complex, where he was physically assaulted by a delivery truck driver. The driver, employed by Enterprise and delivering on behalf of Menards, blocked Mr. Ruhl’s vehicle and refused to move it. After Mr. Ruhl asked the driver to relocate, the driver called him a racial slur and an insult, then struck Mr. Ruhl’s parked vehicle. Mr. Ruhl asked the driver for a business card; in response, the driver, apparently aggravated, exited the truck and punched him in the face. There was also another person in the truck, a passenger—an older Black man—who got out, approached Mr. Ruhl, punched him, and slammed his head to the ground, an act witnessed by Mr. Ruhl’s girlfriend. As a result, Mr. Ruhl sustained head lacerations and back pain. He stated that he has a PR. He also went to the hospital after the incident and noted that he is a smaller, disabled person.

Intake documents were sent via VineSign.

Person Making Contact: Justin
Date & Time: July 22, 2024

Case: Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023
Client: Timothy Ruhl

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Client call back this morning - Returned their call - Maureen is Client's significant other & we have total permission to speak with her - Discussed Incident in a bit more detail - Discussed Treatment - Client is still receiving Pain Management & has FU Injection Appt Aug 1, 2024 - He was being seen at Pain Management of New Albany but now see Dr. Compton, (502) 897-1794 on Dutchmans Lane - Maureen was able to find Def Website with pictures of 1 Def - She will send link to us via Text - Located Def Facebook page - Sent Client photo of possible defendant asking if they can identify the man - awaiting reply - She will also send Client DL & Current PHI Card but Client had different PHI at the time of the incident & no longer has that card - Will need to pull PHI Information from CMR when received - Client & Maureen are happy to hear that we are moving forward & have everything in progress - Discussed Lit Process a bit and advised them it may be Oct or Nov before we need anything additional from them but to be sure to call us with any questions that may come up - They expressed understanding & appreciated the assistance 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: July 26 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on July 26, 2024, with Timothy Ruhl regarding the incident described in the Timothy-Ruhl-Premise file dated 09-14-2023. We returned the client’s call this morning and spoke with him, with Maureen, his significant other, present and holding total permission for us to speak with her. We discussed the incident in more detail and reviewed the treatment plan. The client is still receiving pain management and has a follow-up injection appointment on August 1, 2024. He had been seen at Pain Management of New Albany but is now seeing Dr. Compton at Dutchmans Lane (phone number 502-897-1794).

Maureen located the defendant’s website with pictures of one defendant and will send the link to us via text. She also found the defendant’s Facebook page and sent the client a photo of a possible defendant, asking if he can identify the man; we are awaiting a reply. Maureen will also send the client a copy of his driver’s license and his current PHI card, but the client had a different PHI at the time of the incident and no longer possesses that card. We will need to pull PHI information from the CMR when it is received. The client and Maureen are happy to hear that we are moving forward and that everything is in progress. We discussed the litigation process and advised that it may be October or November before we need anything additional from them, but they should call with any questions that may come up. They expressed understanding and appreciated the assistance. This contact was made by Sarena.

episodes.natural_language: On September 14, 2023, the client, Timothy Ruhl, was contacted to provide an update #cc for the Timothy-Ruhl-Premise case.

For the Timothy-Ruhl-Premise case dated September 14, 2023, the client is Timothy Ruhl.

The note is directed to Aaron W and Bryce 3 and states that the statute of limitations is fast approaching, with less than 60 days remaining. It also notes that no defendants have been identified yet, per the notes. Please advise on how to proceed.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on September 14, 2023 with Timothy Ruhl regarding an assault at his premises. The incident report lists the assailants’ names as Unknown, and the truck involved in the incident was rented through Enterprise. The client stated that they were making deliveries for Menards at the time, but there is no way to prove that claim or to show that the individuals who assaulted the client were Menards employees.

Note from a colleague: “This one might be dead in the water. Not sure how to proceed and coming up on SOL.” The case appears to be at risk of being time-barred, and there are no clear avenues to establish that the assailants were Menards employees or that the deliveries were for Menards. Thoughts on how to proceed were requested.
episodes.author: Bryce Koon

about.relevance: alleged employer / recipient of deliveries (unable to verify)
rental company for the truck involved

episodes.original_body:
Case: Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023
Client: Timothy Ruhl

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd call from Client - Has appt with ENT - ENT is supposed to come to his PCP - Advised Client to Get ENT's name once Appt is set up - Even though ENT is coming to PCP office they may still have their own Bill - Asked about Maureen's Mom's Probate - She passed away in Florida - Gave him the Florida Probate Law Firm Phone # - They offer 30 min Consultations & Maureen can at least get her questions answered & pointed in the right direction - He greatly appreciated the assistance on that - Also discussed current status that we have been awaiting a response from the owner of Hoosier Cargo before filing suit - Explained that we do not actually expect him to respond but still want to give them that chance - BK will reach out once Complaint is actually filed 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: August 13 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Case Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023: On August 13, 2024, Sarena made the initial client contact regarding Timothy Ruhl after receiving his call. He reported that he has an appointment with an ENT, and that the ENT is supposed to come to his PCP. Sarena advised him to obtain the ENT’s name once the appointment is set. Although the ENT will be at the PCP’s office, the ENT may still have their own bill. She also asked about Maureen’s mom’s probate, noting that Maureen’s mom passed away in Florida. Sarena provided him with the Florida Probate Law Firm’s phone number; they offer 30-minute consultations, and Maureen can at least have her questions answered and be pointed in the right direction. The client greatly appreciated this assistance.

Additionally, they discussed the current status that we have been awaiting a response from the owner of Hoosier Cargo before filing suit. Sarena explained that we do not actually expect him to respond but still want to give him that chance. BK will reach out once the complaint is actually filed.

The subject line read: RID 63711710 email expire in 4 days Ruhl. T.

The notification stated that a package had been posted for the recipient and provided a URL to view the package over a secure connection: https://secureftp.uoflhealth.org/human.aspx?OrgID=7565&language=en&Username=sarena%40whaleylawfirm.com&Arg06=181115477&Arg12=message. After viewing the package, the recipient could download any attached files or compose a reply using a web browser. Access to the package requires a password, which would be provided either by the original sender or by another email notification. For assistance, the Help Desk can be reached at 502.588.0411 or servicedesk@uoflhealth.org.

The message concluded with “Regards, Uoflhealth Notification Service Package Resends send request to: amanda.mefford@uoflhealth.org.”

In addition, the note included corporate background: UofL Health, Inc. is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit corporation governed by an independent Board of Directors and is a related organization (as defined under 42 CFR 413.17) with the University of Louisville’s School of Medicine. UofL Health, Inc., on behalf of its teaching hospitals and providers, entered into an academic affiliation agreement with the University of Louisville in which the University of Louisville agreed that its Health Sciences Center would be the academic partner with UofL Health, Inc. to maintain and enhance the University of Louisville’s affiliated graduate medical education as well as its research in medicine, dentistry, nursing and public health.

Case: Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023
Client: Timothy Ruhl

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ BK Filed Complaint - Sent Update Text to Client
Good afternoon Tim,
We just wanted to update you that your claim has now been filed with the Jefferson County Circuit Court. At this time, we are awaiting the Defendants to be served with the complaint. This is usually the most time consuming part of the process. As soon as service has been obtained, the Defendants will have 20-30 days to Answer the complaint. We will reach out once we reach that point to explain the next phase of litigation. However, if you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly at (502) 583-4022 Ext 104 or Bryce at Ext 114. -Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: August 21 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on August 21, 2024, with Sarena of The Whaley Law Firm regarding Timothy Ruhl’s case, Case Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023. The client was informed via text that his claim has now been filed with the Jefferson County Circuit Court. At this time, the firm is awaiting service of the complaint on the defendants. This is typically the most time-consuming part of the process. 

As soon as service has been obtained, the defendants will have 20–30 days to answer the complaint. The firm will reach out again once that point is reached to explain the next phase of litigation. If Tim has any questions, he may contact the firm directly at (502) 583-4022 Ext 104 or Bryce at Ext 114. - Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm

Client: Timothy Ruhl

__Timothy Ruhl - Wife: Maureen (901) 376-5383__
From: Sarena Tuttle [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: Greg Whaley [agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com), Bryce Koon [bryce@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:bryce@whaleylawfirm.com)
CC: 
Date: Tue, 17 Sep 2024 11:13:04 -0400

Hey guys,
 Tim called in this morning and wanted to speak with you about a
situation his wife Maureen is dealing with. Maureen's mother passed away
last month in Florida where she lived. Maureen's Sister, who lives in
Illinois, is the Administrator of the Estate and is refusing to provide
Maureen with any updates as to what is going on with the Estate.
Apparently, there was a Trust set up before Mom's passing and the Sister is
refusing to provide Maureen any information related to the Trust. She is
requesting a letter to the Trustee requesting copies of the
documents associated with the Trust.
 Could one of you please call & discuss with the Client's Wife? I
have advised him, Tim, that with the estate being in Florida, I would not
have the best knowledge of Florida Probate and what they will require.
Also, advised with the Sister being in IL, she may be administrating under
IL Law instead of Florida and that is best answered by one of you or you
could possibly refer them to someone.

Sarena M. Tuttle
Litigation Paralegal &
Workers' Compensation Case Manager
The Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222
D: (502) 357-9971
O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104
E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com
(PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS)
episodes.natural_language:
Case Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023 involves client Timothy Ruhl. His wife is Maureen, who can be reached at (901) 376-5383. On Tuesday, September 17, 2024 at 11:13:04 AM (-0400), Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email from sarena@whaleylawfirm.com to Greg Whaley (agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com) and Bryce Koon (bryce@whaley@whaleylawfirm.com). The message notes there was no CC.

In the body of the email, Sarena explains that Tim called in that morning and wanted to discuss a situation his wife Maureen is dealing with. Maureen’s mother died last month in Florida, where Maureen lived. Maureen’s sister, who lives in Illinois, is the Administrator of the Estate and is refusing to provide Maureen with any updates about what is happening with the Estate. Apparently, there was a Trust set up before Mom’s passing, and the sister is refusing to provide Maureen any information related to the Trust. Maureen is requesting a letter to the Trustee requesting copies of the documents associated with the Trust. Sarena asks that one of the recipients call and discuss the matter with Maureen. She also informs Tim that, since the estate is in Florida, she would not have the best knowledge of Florida probate requirements, and noted that because the sister is in Illinois and may be administering under Illinois law, this is best answered by one of them or by referring them to someone.

The email closes with Sarena M. Tuttle’s signature as follows: Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Direct line: (502) 357-9971; Office line: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; Email: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS).

episodes.natural_language:

Initial client contact on October 1, 2024 with Sarena regarding Timothy Ruhl. The client stated he has been sick with pneumonia for a week, and his doctor has recommended that he move since his apartment is on the third floor. Fortunately, they have just purchased a double-wide.

He has an ear MRI scheduled for Thursday, October 3, at UL Med Center South in Hebron. He is heading to Chicago for a week or so to relax. I advised the client to have a good time, but to plan plenty of stops along the way to stretch his back and to lie across the back seat to decompress if it starts bothering him. The client will call with updates on the ear after the MRI and follow-up visit.

Timothy Ruhl’s case (Request 13380236) was the subject of correspondence between The Whaley Law Firm and HealthMark Group in August and October 2024. On August 9, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; note the new email address), sent an email to HealthMark Group regarding Request 13380236 for Timothy Ruhl. In that message, she stated that they had received an online notification that the Certified Medical Records & Billing Request had been completed, but the downloaded documents did not fulfill the request. Specifically, they had requested Dates of Service from 09/14/2022 through 07/29/2024, but only Dates of Service in 2024 were received; the records did note prior visits in 2023 which were not included. They also had requested Certified Billing, but no billing was provided. She asked HealthMark Group to contact their office to discuss the matter in further detail and noted that they had attached the original request and the provided documents for reference. She also mentioned that they had sent these notes on August 9, 2024 and had been advised that the records and billing would be processed to include any and all visits, including those in 2023. To date, they stated, the complete records and/or billing had not been received, and if there was no billing, a certification page should be sent stating that no billing was available. The message concluded with Sarena’s contact details and a reminder of the new email address.

Earlier in the same thread, Sarena also forwarded the same information in an initial message dated August 9, 2024 at 9:28 AM, reiterating that they had received a notification that the Certified Medical Records & Billing Request had been completed but the request was not fulfilled in full: the Dates of Service requested (09/14/2022 through 07/29/2024) were not fully provided, with 2023 visits missing and no Certified Billing provided. She again requested that HealthMark Group contact their office to discuss the matter and attached the original request and documents for reference. This message likewise included The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information and noted the firm’s intent to address the matter promptly, including the new email address for Sarena.

On the same day, HealthMark Group replied to the August 9, 2024 outreach. In a message dated August 9, 2024 (around 3:28 PM), HealthMark Group stated that they had submitted Request ID 13380236 for the reprocessing of the medical records indicated in the email. Regarding Billing, their processor indicated that there are currently no billing records available in the patient’s chart, and they requested that the firm allow some time for reprocessing of the medical records. The reply was signed by Cortney Wyatt of HealthMark Group, with the firm’s Dallas, Texas address listed as 325 N. Saint Paul Street, Ste. 1650, Dallas, TX 75201.

episodes.natural_language:
Timothy Ruhl’s case, filed as Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023, centers on Request 13380236 for certified medical records and billing. The client is Timothy Ruhl. Communications regarding this request were exchanged between HealthMark Group and The Whaley Law Firm, represented by Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager.

On August 9, 2024, at 9:28 AM, Sarena Tuttle sent an email to HealthMark Group (HealthMark Group) reporting that their Certified Medical Records & Billing Request had been completed online, but the download did not fulfill the request. She stated that the dates of service requested were 09/14/2022 through 07/29/2024, yet only dates of service in 2024 were received. The provided records did not include prior visits in 2023, and certified billing was not provided. She asked HealthMark to contact their office to discuss the matter in further detail and noted that she had attached the original request and the provided documents for reference. Her message included her contact information and reminded that this is The Whaley Law Firm’s new email address for correspondence.

Later that day, at approximately 3:28 PM, HealthMark Group replied via Cortney Wyatt, stating that they had submitted the request ID 13380236 for reprocessing of the medical records indicated in the email. They noted that, according to the processor, there were currently no billing records available in the patient’s chart and asked for patience while the medical records were reprocessed.

Earlier correspondence from Sarena on August 9, 2024 had reiterated the same concerns: the notification indicated the records and billing had been processed, but the actual delivery was incomplete. She again requested dates of service 09/14/2022 through 07/29/2024, highlighted that only 2024 dates were received, and pointed out that prior visits in 2023 were not included. She reaffirmed that certified billing was not provided and requested contact to discuss the matter further. She attached the original request and the documents for reference and again provided her contact details, including her note that the email address to reach her had changed to Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

Following these exchanges, on October 1, 2024 at 10:31 AM, Sarena Tuttle responded to HealthMark Group. She reported that they had received an online notification stating that their Certified Medical Records & Billing Request had been completed; however, upon downloading the available documents, the request remained incomplete. She specified that the Dates of Service requested were 09/14/2022 through 07/29/2024, but only 2024 dates appeared in the records. The records did note prior visits in 2023, which were not included, and Certified Billing was still not provided. She requested a discussion with HealthMark to resolve the matter and stated that they had attached the original request and the provided documents for reference. She also noted that they had sent similar notes on August 9, 2024, and were advised that the records and billing would be processed to include all visits, including those in 2023, but to date they had not received the complete records and/or billing. She added that if there is no billing, the certification page should be sent stating no billing is available. The email included her full signature block, including her title, firm, address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), direct line (502) 357-9971, office line (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and her email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note emphasizing the new email address.

On October 2, 2024, at 4:27 PM, HealthMark Group responded to the correspondence. They stated that it did not appear that any new records had been added to the request and that they had sent the matter back for another search to locate the missing records, as well as to complete the CNR for billing. The message was signed by Brittany Doyle of HealthMark Group, with the company’s address listed as 325 N. Saint Paul Street, Ste. 1650, Dallas, TX 75201.

 Request ID Access Code Patient Name Your Reference 13380236 744850 TIMOTHY RUHL TIMOTHY RUHL 
 
 
 HealthMark Group is here to HELP! We partner with healthcare practices and staff to streamline operations and compliance

Case: Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023. Client: Timothy Ruhl.

On Friday, October 4, 2024 at 05:00:32 UTC, HealthMark Group sent an email from status@healthmark-group.com to sarena@whaleylawfirm.com regarding the request for medical records for Timothy Ruhl (PHI request ID 13380236). The subject line indicates the matter is “Regarding Requests for Medical Records - 13380236,” and the message is labeled as a “Download Notification” with a note that a complimentary download is available.

The body of the email states that the request for Protected Health Information (PHI) is complete and ready for download. To access the records immediately, the recipient is instructed to visit https://requestmanager.healthmark-group.com/register and enter their email to receive a secure link. Once on the Request Manager Dashboard, the recipient should select the option “Have a Download Letter?” Then, using the information provided, enter the Request ID and Access Code as listed. It is also noted that to download an available record, the patient’s Date of Birth is required. The PHI is available for 30 days following the date the request is complete. For questions, contact status@healthmark-group.com. A garbled segment appears in the text: https://requestmanager.healthmark-group.com/registerm: CAPITOL PAIN INSTITUTE - LOUISVILLE.

The message then presents the specific details of the request: Request ID 13380236, Access Code 744850, Patient Name TIMOTHY RUHL, Your Reference TIMOTHY RUHL. A line following these details reiterates the contact and service orientation of HealthMark Group.

The email includes a promotional paragraph describing HealthMark Group’s role and capabilities. It states that HealthMark Group helps healthcare practices and staff streamline operations and compliance and improve the overall patient experience, with services ranging from Release of Information, Audit and Chart Review Support, Clinical Form Support Services, to Digital Patient Check-in. The company positions itself as an industry leader in the secure digital exchange of Protected Health Information and invites readers to learn more about its technology and solutions at www.healthmark-group.com or by emailing info@healthmark-group.com.

The transmission also contains a standard privacy notice: it may contain information that is privileged, confidential, and/or exempt from disclosure under applicable law. If you are not the intended recipient, any disclosure, copying, distribution, or use of the information is strictly prohibited. If received in error, the sender should be contacted immediately and the material destroyed in its entirety, whether in electronic or hard copy format.

Client: Timothy Ruhl

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Calls from Client this morning - 3 almost back to back - sent Text advising I would call him this afternoon 

Called Client & previously promised - Client states he went ENT CT Scan - Ear is unrepairable - Ruptured Membrane - ENT 502-817-7300 Michael Brown - Does not effect hearing but sounds like wind tunnel off and on - Advised we will send CRR for the records 

Client is currently out fishing and unable to go over DC Disc Req - Scheduled to Conference any time on Friday 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: October 16 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023. Client: Timothy Ruhl. On October 16, 2024, Sarena made contact with the client after he had reported receiving three calls this morning in rapid succession and had sent a text advising that I would call him this afternoon. The client stated that he recently underwent an ENT CT scan and that his ear is unrepairable due to a ruptured tympanic membrane. The ENT contact is Michael Brown at 502-817-7300. The client noted that this condition does not affect his hearing but produces sounds like a wind tunnel off and on. We advised that a CRR would be sent for the records.

The client is currently out fishing and unable to go over the DC Disc Req. He is scheduled to conference at any time on Friday. This contact was made by Sarena on October 16, 2024.

Client: Timothy Ruhl

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Call Back from Client & S/O - Reviewed DC Disc Req - They are going out of town next week to Chicago for vacation - Discussed what's to come after written discovery - Discussed we anticipate DC will drag out written discovery & to please be patient - Client & S/O expressed understanding - Discussed Depos briefly - Client does not want to be in the same building w/Defendants - Prefers we schedule his & Maureen (Witness) Deposition on separate date from Defendants - Advised we will try to do a Zoom Depo if DC Willing - Advised will discuss further when we get to that phase - Client & S/O expressed appreciation & understanding of current status & process 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: October 21 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on October 21, 2024, for case Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023 with client Timothy Ruhl. The contact was made by Sarena. We received a callback from the client and his S/O and reviewed the DC Discovery Request. They are going out of town next week to Chicago for vacation. We discussed what’s to come after written discovery and noted that we anticipate the DC will drag out the written discovery and asked them to please be patient. The client and S/O expressed understanding.

We briefly discussed deposits. The client does not want to be in the same building as the Defendants and prefers we schedule his deposition and Maureen (Witness) deposition on a separate date from the Defendants. We advised we will try to do a Zoom deposition if DC is willing and that we will discuss further when we get to that phase. The client and S/O expressed appreciation and understanding of the current status and process.
episodes.author: Filevine Integration

The caller indicated that they would visit the office after the vacation to review what was missing, or, if the issue is minor, to call the number provided. The message notes that it can be listened to via the recipient’s phone or by logging into the RingCentral account with the main number, extension, and password, and that voicemails can also be managed within the RingCentral account.

__Certified Medical Records & Billing Request - Overdue - Approaching 90 Days__
From: Sarena Tuttle [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: KBullard@entcc.com 
CC: 
Date: Wed, 8 Jan 2025 14:40:15 -0500

Good afternoon Mrs. Bullard,
 Please find attached our office's request for Certified Medical
Records & Billing on our Client Timothy Ruhl, DOB 08/05/1966. Our original
request was faxed in on October 16, 2024. We sent a follow up Request on
December 20, 2024 and still have received no response from your office.
 Please expedite these records & bills for inclusion to the courts. We
are on a Discovery Deadline and if we do not properly submit your records
and bills, they can be excluded from payment consideration by the
responsible party and/or courts. If you have any questions, please do not
hesitate to contact us directly.

Sarena M. Tuttle
Litigation Paralegal &
Workers' Compensation Case Manager
The Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222
D: (502) 357-9971
O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104
E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com
(PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS)
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023 centers on client Timothy Ruhl, born August 5, 1966. On January 8, 2025, at 2:40 PM Eastern Time, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager with The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Mrs. Bullard at KBullard@entcc.com with the subject “Certified Medical Records & Billing Request - Overdue - Approaching 90 Days.” In the body, she states that the attached documents constitute the office’s request for certified medical records and billing for their client, Timothy Ruhl. She notes that the original request was faxed on October 16, 2024, and a follow-up request was sent on December 20, 2024, yet there has been no response from the recipient’s office. She asks that the records and bills be expedited for inclusion in the courts, highlighting that there is a discovery deadline and that failure to properly submit the records and bills could result in their exclusion from payment consideration by the responsible party and/or by the courts. She concludes by inviting any questions and directs correspondence to her.

The message is signed by Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her direct line is (502) 357-9971, and her office line is (502) 583-4022 ext 104. She can be reached by email at Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating this is her new email address.

episodes.natural_language:
Case Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023 for Timothy Ruhl. Initial client contact on January 15, 2025 with Sarena regarding Timothy Ruhl’s case. The client returned the call and stated that they had received a letter from PHI Acadia and will send in a copy of the letter.

The client is also having issues with a new home, which was purchased in October and is not yet set on a foundation, with a move required by March 24, 2025. We advised that we can reach out to the Home Company after February 1, 2025 if the foundation is still not set. The client is concerned about extra storage fees and hotel fees, and we advised that we would revisit the issue in February if it remains unresolved.

Reviewing activity in Timothy Ruhl A/B 9/14/2023 between 12/25/2024 and 1/24/2025...

This case involves Timothy Ruhl suing Hoosier Cargo Express, LLC and other defendants for an incident that resulted in injuries requiring ongoing medical treatment. The case is currently in the litigation phase, with discovery proceedings underway.
The most recent activity includes the plaintiff's attorney filing and serving discovery responses to the defense counsel on January 3, 2025. The attorney also provided a Dropbox link for document production related to these responses. (See details)
A potential red flag is the client's ongoing housing situation. Timothy Ruhl purchased a new home in October but is experiencing delays in setting it on the foundation. He has to move by March 24, 2025, and is concerned about potential extra storage and hotel fees. (See details)
The next steps include following up on medical records requests, particularly from ENT, which are overdue and approaching 90 days since the initial request. episodes.natural_language:
In the Timothy Ruhl Premise case (Case Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023), the client is Timothy Ruhl. He is suing Hoosier Cargo Express, LLC and other defendants for an incident that resulted in injuries requiring ongoing medical treatment. The matter is in the litigation phase with discovery underway. The most recent activity occurred on January 3, 2025, when the plaintiff's attorney filed and served discovery responses on defense counsel, and the attorney provided a Dropbox link for document production related to these responses.

A potential red flag in this case is the client's ongoing housing situation. Timothy Ruhl purchased a new home in October but there have been delays in setting it on the foundation. He must move by March 24, 2025, and he is concerned about potential extra storage and hotel fees during the transition.

The next steps include following up on medical records requests, particularly from ENT, which are overdue and approaching 90 days since the initial request. It is crucial to obtain these records to meet discovery deadlines and ensure they are not excluded from payment consideration.

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Client Missed Call Notice - Attempted to Whispering Oaks again since no return call - S/w Melissa - Refused to Discussed - Passed message to Esq Jody Gable - Recvd Call from Esq Gable - Discussed current status of Home Placement - Was supposed to be set today but equipment broke - Part is on the way - Should be set tomorrow - Snow should not be a delay but no guarantee - She will keep us posted - Returned Client Call - Provided him update - He s/w Regional around same time I s/w Esq - He is stressed about situation - Advised they estimate 2 weeks & will keep us posted on progress - Discussed Claim - Advised still working on Disc Phase - Will discuss more once in Oral Disc - Client expressed understanding & appreciated the assistance 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: February 11 2025
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on February 11, 2025, with Timothy Ruhl regarding the Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023 case. The log notes a missed client call, and Social Worker Sarena attempted to reach Whispering Oaks again since there was no return call. The social worker Melissa refused to discuss, and the message was passed to Esq Jody Gable. A call was received from Esq Gable, and the current status of Home Placement was discussed. It was supposed to be set today but the equipment broke; a part is on the way and it should be set tomorrow. Snow should not be a delay but there is no guarantee. She will keep us posted.

Returned client call and provided him an update. He spoke with Regional around the same time I spoke with Esq. He is stressed about the situation. We advised they estimate 2 weeks and will keep us posted on progress. We discussed the Claim and advised still working on Disc Phase—will discuss more once in Oral Disc. The client expressed understanding and appreciated the assistance.

Gabel, General Counsel for Flagship Communities REIT, and Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, regarding the Whispering Oaks home purchase for the Ruhl family. The emails include the parties’ contact information and standard confidentiality notices.

On February 11, 2025, at 2:02 PM, Jody B. Gabel wrote to Sarena Tuttle. She thanked Sarena for calling back and explained that their plan was to have the home set on the lot the following day. Jody stated she would provide an email update on Thursday to report the status and invited Sarena to email or call her cell at 859-475-9298 if there were any additional questions. Jody’s message also included her work details: Flagship Communities REIT, 2220 Grandview Drive, Suite 280, Fort Mitchell, KY 41017; office phone 859-342-5111 ext. 128; mobile 859-475-9298; and her email jbgabel@flagshipcommunities.com. Each message carried an IMPORTANT/CONFIDENTIAL disclaimer indicating the information may be privileged or confidential and that unauthorized distribution is prohibited.

Later on February 11, 2025 at 2:56? PM, Sarena Tuttle replied: “Good afternoon Mrs. Gabel, Thank you so much for clarifying the current status of the situation. It was a pleasure to speak with you and be able to provide Tim & Maureen a little stress relief. We look forward to hearing from you.” Sarena signed as before with her title, The Whaley Law Firm, and contact information: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; office 502-583-4022 ext 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note asking the recipient to note the new email address.

On February 13, 2025 at 1:42 PM, Sarena Tuttle sent another message to Jody Gabel (cc’d to Bryce Koon). The message began with the line, “You don’t often get email from sarena@whaleylawfirm.com. Learn why this is important,” followed by: “Good afternoon Jody, We just wanted to touch base as discussed earlier this week. Any updates we can pass along?” Sarena again closed with her standard signature and reminder about her contact details and new email address, along with the same confidentiality notice.

Finally, on February 13, 2025 at 7:15 PM (19:15), Jody B. Gabel replied with an update. She said she had planned to provide an end-of-business update that day as previously advised. She confirmed with Flagship’s Regional Manager that the home setters were on site that day, assembling the two sections of the doublewide home and joining them. The setters were scheduled to return the next day to finish any loose ends. They were still waiting for an update on the water and sewer connection. The Regional Manager had noted that their clients were on site observing the work in progress. Jody added that she would provide a further update if there was any new information about the water/sewer and electric connections the following day. Her email signature again included Flagship Communities REIT’s details and contact information, along with the customary confidential disclaimer.

Across all messages, the correspondence repeatedly references the Whispering Oaks – Ruhl Home Purchase, the progress of constructing the doublewide home on the lot, and pending water, sewer, and electric connections, with both sides communicating in a timely manner and noting on-site observations by the clients.

episodes.natural_language:
In February 2025, the Whispering Oaks project involving Timothy Ruhl progressed through a series of updates between The Whaley Law Firm and Flagship Communities REIT. The note begins with Jody B. Gabel, Flagship’s General Counsel, outlining a plan on February 11, 2025: the home was to be set on the lot the next day, with an email update to follow on Thursday. She noted that her team would provide further information as the situation evolved.

On February 13, 2025, Gabel reported that home setters were putting the doublewide together, joining the two sections of the structure. The setters would return the following day to finish up any loose ends. The team was waiting on an update for the water and sewer connection, and the Regional Manager had advised that the clients were on site observing the work in progress. Gabel indicated she would provide an update if there was any new information on the water/sewer and electric connections the next day.

Also on February 13, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm replied, noting she doesn’t often receive email from sarena@whaleylawfirm.com, and asking for any updates that could be passed along. She and Jody had discussed keeping Tim and Maureen informed about progress.

A subsequent message from Jody on February 14 confirmed the planned sequence of work: the home setters were at the site that day, joining the two sections of the doublewide, with the setters scheduled to return the next day to finish up remaining tasks. Electric hookup was scheduled for Monday, and water/sewer hookup for Tuesday. The Regional Manager was also to meet with the company constructing the deck on Wednesday to review the plans. Gabel cautioned that the schedule was subject to an incoming weather pattern predicting several inches of rain, and she emphasized that the team remained committed to moving forward with the setup. She promised to provide an update on Thursday, depending on how the weather affected progress.

On February 18, 2025, Jody Gabel sent the latest update. She stated that the home was set and the siding was completed. Water and sewer were scheduled for hookup that day, but she had not yet received confirmation. She noted that there might be a delay due to weather conditions and that the ETA for electric hookup was also being impacted by the weather. She added that as soon as any update was available, she would pass it along.

Throughout these exchanges, the case remained focused on the Whispering Oaks – Ruhl Home Purchase for Timothy Ruhl, with Jody Gabel representing Flagship Communities REIT and Sarena Tuttle handling communications on behalf of The Whaley Law Firm.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023
Client: Timothy Ruhl

Re: Whispering Oaks - Ruhl Home Purchase

In February 2025, communications concerning the Whispering Oaks - Ruhl Home Purchase were exchanged between The Whaley Law Firm and Flagship Communities REIT regarding client Timothy Ruhl. The messages also reference Tim and Maureen in connection with the purchase and development of the home, and they include standard confidentiality and privilege notices typical of corporate email correspondence.

The first set of messages began on February 11, 2025. At 2:56 PM, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm wrote to Jody B. Gabel of Flagship Communities REIT to thank her for clarifying the current status of the situation. Sarena noted that it had been a pleasure speaking with Jody and that she and her clients, Tim and Maureen, appreciated the update and stress relief the clarification provided. The email included Sarena’s contact information and a note that her email address is sarena@whaleylawfirm.com, along with the firm’s mailing address and phone numbers.

Jody responded later that same day, February 11, 2025, at 2:02 PM. She thanked Sarena for returning the call and explained that the plan was to have the home set on the lot the following day. She stated she would provide an email update on Thursday with the status and urged Sarena to contact her cell or email if there were additional questions.

A further reply from Sarena arrived on February 13, 2025, at 1:42 PM. Her message began with a brief note that “You don’t often get email from sarena@whaleylawfirm.com,” and then she asked Jody for any updates that could be passed along.

That same day, February 13, 2025, at 2:15 PM, Jody sent another update. He explained that, according to the Regional Manager, the home setters were placing the home together by joining the two sections of the doublewide that day. The setters were expected to return the next day to finish any loose ends. They were waiting on an update for water and sewer connections, and the Regional Manager had observed the clients on site and viewing the progress. Jody also noted that the Regional Manager would provide any new information on water/sewer and electric connections the following day.

On February 14, 2025, at 3:23 PM, Jody followed up again. He reported that, after checking with the Regional Manager, the home setters were on site finishing the process of assembling the home—specifically joining the two sections of the doublewide. He stated that electric hookup was scheduled for Monday and water/sewer hookup was scheduled for Tuesday. The Regional Manager was also set to meet with the company responsible for constructing the deck on Wednesday to review the plans. Jody added that the schedule was subject to an incoming weather pattern, including the prediction of several inches of rain, and that the team remained committed to moving forward with the setup. He promised to provide an update on Monday to reflect how the weather over the weekend affected the plan.

The most recent communications occurred on February 18, 2025. At approximately 1:45 PM, Jody informed Sarena that the home was set and the siding had been completed. He stated that water and sewer hookups were scheduled for that day but that he had not yet received confirmation, and there could be a delay due to weather conditions. He also indicated that the ETA for electric hookup had been impacted by the weather, and that he would pass along any updates as they became available.

In the late afternoon of February 18, 2025, at 1:56 PM (13:56:27 -0500), Sarena replied with appreciation for the update and good wishes. She noted the recent severe flooding in the area around the Park over the weekend and expressed hope that the park itself had not been badly affected. She indicated that they looked forward to further updates as the situation progressed.

Throughout these exchanges, the messages from Flagship Communities REIT repeatedly included standard confidentiality and privilege notices, stating that the communication was intended only for the addressees, that the information may be privileged or confidential, and that forwarding or distribution was strictly prohibited. The notices also instructed recipients who were not the intended recipients to return the message and destroy it.

episodes.natural_language:
In February 2025, the Whispering Oaks development concerning the Ruhl home purchase was the subject of a series of update emails from Jody B. Gabel, General Counsel for Flagship Communities REIT, to Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal at The Whaley Law Firm, with ongoing notes about the progress of setting the home on the lot and the related utility and construction work.

On February 11, 2025, Jody advised that the home was being set and the two sections of the doublewide were being joined that day, with setters expected to return the following day to finish up loose ends. The water and sewer hookup had not yet been confirmed, and there was mention that the status could be affected by weather conditions. She noted that our Regional Manager reported that their clients were on site observing the work in progress, and she promised to provide an update if there was any new information on the water/sewer and electric connections.

Two days later, on February 13, 2025, Jody reported that the home setters were joining the two sections of the doublewide that day, with plans for the setters to return the next day to complete any remaining tasks. She indicated that water and sewer connections were still awaiting an update, and that weather conditions might influence the timeline. She stated that their Regional Manager had observed the clients on site. The schedule was electric hookup on Monday, water/sewer hookup on Tuesday, and a meeting with the deck builder on Wednesday to review plans. She acknowledged that the schedule could be affected by an incoming weather pattern forecast to bring several inches of rain and reaffirmed the team’s commitment to moving forward, with a Monday update anticipated to reflect any weather impacts.

On February 14, 2025, she again confirmed progress: workers were at the home finishing up the setup, electric hookup was planned for Monday, and water/sewer hookup was planned for Tuesday. The Regional Manager was set to meet with the company constructing the deck on Wednesday to go over the plans. She cautioned that the schedule was subject to the incoming weather and promised another update on Monday to assess weekend weather effects and next steps.

By February 18, 2025, Jody provided another status update. She stated that the home was set and siding completed, and that water and sewer were scheduled for setup that day, though she had not yet received confirmation. She warned that there could be a delay due to weather conditions and noted that the ETA for electric hookup had also been impacted by the weather. She pledged to pass along any updates as soon as they became available.

Finally, on February 21, 2025, at 18:10:12 UTC, Jody sent a forward indicating that the water/sewer lines were being connected to the main water supply and that the electric hookup was being performed that day. She added that deck installation would begin at the beginning of the next week and that she would provide another update on Monday afternoon.

Across these communications, the consistent thread was ongoing progress with setting the home, progress on utility hookups, planned deck construction, and weather-related potential delays, all within the context of the Whispering Oaks – Ruhl Home Purchase.

Per Client has Mold issue at current apartment since Water Leak in November. Client provided photographs - Called Park Lake - Requested Maintenance Inspection of Apartment - Also contacted Park Lake Rep - LVM - Filed Code Enforcement Complaint on Client behalf - included Mold & Damage photos
episodes.natural_language:
This case concerns Timothy Ruhl ( Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023 ). The client reports a mold issue in his current apartment that has persisted since a water leak in November. He provided photographs illustrating the mold and related damage.

He called Park Lake to request a maintenance inspection of the apartment and also contacted a Park Lake representative, LVM. A Code Enforcement Complaint was filed on the client’s behalf, and it included photographs of the mold and the associated damage.

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Client Update - Mobile Home almost Ready - Together - Siding On - Water/Sewer Connected - Electric in Progress on Friday - Deck Installation should be today - Possible Final Inspection by end of week

Client mentioned Mold issue at current apartment - Advised to send in Photos - Did not expect severity to be so bad upon Photo Review - Called Park Lake s/w Zach - Requested Maintenance Inspection & Mold be addressed - Also LVM for Park Lake Attorney (John 859-231-0099) - Client requested C/B - Called - Maintenance completed Inspection/applied mold treatment & stated Client should not be worried since they are moving - Advised Client filed Louisville Code Enforcement Complaint on his behalf - They will send someone out to inspect as well - Client advised several tenants are moving due to mold issue - Advised Client to mention to City Inspector when they come out - Client again appreciated assistance with this matter 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: February 24 2025
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on February 24, 2025, with Sarena regarding Timothy Ruhl (Case: Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023). The update indicates the mobile home is almost ready. Progress includes siding on, water and sewer connected, and electric work in progress on Friday. Deck installation should be completed today, and a possible final inspection by the end of the week.

Regarding the mold issue at the current apartment, the client reported mold concerns and was advised to send in photos; he did not expect the severity to be so bad upon photo review. He called Park Lake s/w Zach and requested a maintenance inspection and that mold be addressed, and he also requested LVM for Park Lake Attorney (John 859-231-0099). The client requested C/B. Maintenance completed the inspection, applied mold treatment, and stated the client should not be worried since they are moving. I advised the client that Louisville Code Enforcement Complaint had been filed on his behalf, and they will send someone out to inspect as well. The client advised several tenants are moving due to the mold issue. We advised the client to mention to the City Inspector when they come out. The client again appreciated the assistance with this matter.

Subject: 7343 Leisure Court, Louisville, KY 40229 - Timothy Ruhl & Maureen Abrasevic

Good morning Mr. Strom,
 Just to clarify, our office represents Mr. Timothy Ruhl for an unrelated matter. We contacted the Property Office and they requested we contact you. However, he & Maureen Abrasevic, reached out to us in regard to the housing issue. They provided the attached pictures yesterday and stated that the ceiling fell in, in November and the complex has done nothing about the mold or water damage. They did patch the ceiling, but there seems to still be moisture in the ceiling/walls. From our understanding multiple units are affected and several tenants are being forced to move due to the issue. Our client is in the process of moving out as well and simply requests their February Rent be refunded and not to be charged for March. They will vacate the property by the end of March as they are simply awaiting a final inspection of their new home to be scheduled. They are very concerned that the property office will simply find a new tenant & not address the concerns properly. We look forward to hearing from you once your investigation into the matter is complete.

__Re: 7343 Leisure Court, Louisville, KY 40229 - Timothy Ruhl & Maureen Abrasevic__
From: Jon Strom [jstrom@andersoncommunities.com](mailto:jstrom@andersoncommunities.com)
To: Sarena Tuttle [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com)
CC: 
Date: Wed, 26 Feb 2025 19:47:58 +0000

Good afternoon, Ms. Tuttle,

Thank you for sending this information. I've discussed the matter with Property Management and reviewed the work order history for this rental unit. We respectfully reject your demand for February and March Rent. The photos you've provided seem to involve three separate maintenance requests which occurred over several months and were all addressed in a timely manner: a roof leak, an open window creating condensation and a mold spot discovered behind a piece of furniture. Each matter was addressed within a matter of days after the resident notified Resident Services. Please note that the Resident's lease includes a mold and mildew addendum outlining steps that must be taken in the event the resident suspects a mold issue. Furthermore, the Kentucky Landlord Tenant Act provides a notice and opportunity to cure process that has not been followed by the resident.

If the attorney representing Mr. Ruhl (who is not a party to the written lease) would like to discuss this further, please have him or her contact me using the information below. Though I am admittedly unclear as to Whaley Law Firm's representation in this matter, I am happy to provide any clarification that may be necessary.

Thank you,

D. Jonathan Strom

General Counsel | Anderson Communities ¦

From: Sarena Tuttle 
Sent: Tuesday, February 25, 2025 9:55 AM
To: Jon Strom 
Subject: 7343 Leisure Court, Louisville, KY 40229 - Timothy Ruhl & Maureen Abrasevic

Good morning Mr. Strom,
 Just to clarify, our office represents Mr. Timothy Ruhl for an unrelated matter. We contacted the Property Office and they requested we contact you. However, he & Maureen Abrasevic, reached out to us in regard to the housing issue. They provided the attached pictures yesterday and stated that the ceiling fell in, in November and the complex has done nothing about the mold or water damage. They did patch the ceiling, but there seems to still be moisture in the ceiling/walls. From our understanding multiple units are affected and several tenants are being forced to move due to the issue. Our client is in the process of moving out as well and simply requests their February Rent be refunded and not to be charged for March. They will vacate the property by the end of March as they are simply awaiting a final inspection of their new home to be scheduled. They are very concerned that the property office will simply find a new tenant & not address the concerns properly. We look forward to hearing from you once your investigation into the matter is complete.

Sarena M. Tuttle
Litigation Paralegal &
Workers' Compensation Case Manager
The Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222
D: (502) 357-9971
O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104
E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com
(PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS)
episodes.natural_language:
In the matter of 7343 Leisure Court, Louisville, KY 40229, Timothy Ruhl and Maureen Abrasevic, the client is Timothy Ruhl. The case note dated September 14, 2023, records correspondence between Jon Strom, General Counsel for Anderson Communities, and Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm regarding a housing issue at the Leisure Court property. The Re line identifies the property and the tenants, Timothy Ruhl and Maureen Abrasevic.

On February 25, 2025, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to Mr. Strom. She clarified that her office represents Mr. Timothy Ruhl for an unrelated matter, but that Mr. Ruhl and Ms. Abrasevic had reached out regarding the housing issue. They had provided photographs the previous day and stated that a ceiling had fallen in November, that the complex had done nothing about the mold or water damage, and that although the ceiling had been patched, there remains moisture in the ceiling and walls. They alleged that multiple units were affected and that several tenants were being forced to move due to the issue. The clients were in the process of moving out and requested that their February rent be refunded and that they not be charged for March. They planned to vacate the property by the end of March, pending a final inspection of their new home, and they expressed concern that the property office would simply find a new tenant without addressing the concerns. They indicated they looked forward to hearing from Mr. Strom once the investigation into the matter was complete. Tuttle provided her contact details at The Whaley Law Firm, including her new email address.

The following day, February 26, 2025, Jon Strom responded to Ms. Tuttle. He stated that he had discussed the matter with Property Management and had reviewed the work order history for the rental unit. Anderson Communities respectfully rejected the demand for February and March rent. He explained that the photos provided appeared to reflect three separate maintenance requests that occurred over several months and were all addressed in a timely manner: a roof leak, an open window that created condensation, and a mold spot discovered behind a piece of furniture. Each issue was addressed within a matter of days after the resident notified Resident Services. Strom noted that the lease includes a mold and mildew addendum outlining the steps to be taken if the resident suspects a mold issue. He also pointed out that the Kentucky Landlord-Tenant Act provides a notice and opportunity-to-cure process that, in his view, has not been followed by the resident. Finally, he invited any attorney representing Mr. Ruhl—who is not a party to the written lease—to contact him to discuss the matter further and indicated he was willing to provide any necessary clarification, though he was unclear as to Whaley Law Firm’s representation in the matter. Strom provided his contact information and office details for follow-up.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Client VM - Returned his call - Finally moved into new place - S/w BK a bit yesterday - BK advised he sent 'astronomical' Demand to initiate negotiations - Discussed Demand & Negotiations a bit - Advised no sense discussing currently dollar amount of Demand as it is unrealistic & will not be the settlement amount - Client Expressed understanding - Advised Client that BK will reach out once Initial Offer is made (if any) & to grant BK Permission to negotiate to the LBF - Reassured Client we will not accept LBF without discussing it with him - Client & S/O appreciated the update & look forward to getting things wrapped up soon 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: March 12 2025
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on March 12, 2025, with Timothy Ruhl after Sarena returned his voicemail. He had recently moved into a new place. Sarena spoke with BK a bit yesterday; BK advised that he had sent an "astronomical" Demand to initiate negotiations. They discussed the Demand and the negotiations briefly.

Sarena advised Timothy that there is no point discussing the current dollar amount of the Demand since it is unrealistic and will not be the settlement amount. The client expressed understanding. She advised Timothy that BK will reach out once an Initial Offer is made (if any) and to grant BK permission to negotiate to the LBF. She reassured him that we will not accept the LBF without discussing it with him. The client and his S/O appreciated the update and look forward to getting things wrapped up soon.

Case: Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023. Client: Timothy Ruhl. The following narrative summarizes the email communications between The Whaley Law Firm and Carelon Subrogation concerning Timothy Ruhl (case number 149197622) and the related lien and treatment records.

On March 6, 2025, Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an external email to Christopher Sullivan of Carelon Subrogation regarding Timothy Ruhl (149197622). The message, which was CC’d to Sarena Tuttle and Timothy Ruhl’s Filevine project email TimothyRuhlDOIZ4668241@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, addressed the Timothy Ruhl lien statement. Koon stated that after reviewing the previously-provided lien statement, none of the listed charges appeared to be related to the incident at issue in their litigation. He noted that Mr. Ruhl has an extensively documented history of chronic back pain and low back injuries, and he argued that these charges should be removed as they are not related to their claim. He requested that Sullivan review the charges and provide an updated ledger reflecting any related payments at the earliest convenience. The email concluded with Koon’s signature and contained The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. The message also included a standard attorney-client confidential notice, stating that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged or protected information, and that if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and not disclose or forward the information to others.

On March 10, 2025, Christopher Sullivan, a Subrogation Analyst for Carelon Subrogation, replied to Bryce Koon. Sullivan asked for confirmation of the injuries being claimed and the last date of treatment to ensure the lien’s accuracy before removing all claims and closing the file. His message provided Carelon’s contact information: P.O. Box 659940, San Antonio, TX 78265-9939; Office phone: (502) 889-2010; fax: (844) 634-2520; email: christopher.sullivan@carelon.com. The reply also contained Carelon’s note that the company is paperless and requested that documentation be submitted in a single format (fax, email, or via website) to expedite a response.

Finally, on April 15, 2025, at 03:22:58 GMT-04:00, Bryce Koon sent a follow-up email to Christopher Sullivan. In this message, Koon stated that the majority of the treatment he had for Timothy Ruhl originated from the week of September 14, 2023, and that this treatment was mostly head and face-related. He added that the only other treatment identified as potentially related involved pain-management procedures, but the last date of service for those was November 10, 2023. The email was signed by W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, with the same firm contact details as before. The message again included The Whaley Law Firm’s confidentiality notice, indicating that the electronic communication is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged information, with instructions to contact the firm if received in error and not to use or forward the information.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023
Client: Timothy Ruhl

In the matter of Timothy Ruhl v. Hoosier Cargo, et al. (Jefferson 24-CI-005896), the following communications occurred concerning deposition scheduling and a global settlement demand. The client in this matter is Timothy Ruhl.

On April 15, 2025, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email titled “Timothy Ruhl v. Hoosier Cargo, et al. (Jefferson 24-CI-005896)” to Charles Walker and tmarak@sonlegal.com, with William Orberson and Allison Wiles also included, and Timothy Ruhl copied via his Filevine project email address TimothyRuhlDOIZ4668241@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com. The message was addressed to Allison Wiles at PPOA Law and carried the subject line reflecting the case caption. Koon advised that attached was Plaintiff’s global settlement demand and stated that this would be the easiest method for everyone involved. He provided a Dropbox link for the documents: https://www.dropbox.com/t/B0AZo8uqazDxAEEC. The email closed with Koon’s signature, including The Whaley Law Firm’s address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222) and contact information (Phone: 502-365-5043; Fax: 502-237-3207). A standard confidentiality notice followed, indicating the message was intended only for the named recipient and warning against redistribution or disclosure if received in error.

On April 16, 2025, at 10:32 AM, Allison Wiles (Allie Orberson-Wiles) replied. She thanked Bryce for the demand and stated that the firm could not formally respond until they had Mr. Ruhl’s deposition. She requested that Bryce inform them when Mr. Ruhl would be available for his deposition. She invited further discussion if there were questions. The reply included her direct line (502-560-9955) and office line (502-583-9900), her email (aorberson-wiles@ppoalaw.com), and the firm’s office address (716 West Main Street, Suite 300, Louisville, KY 40202). The firm’s standard confidentiality disclaimer followed in the signature block, noting the privileged nature of the communication and instructing the recipient to contact the sender to report an error if the message was received in error.

Earlier, on April 15, 2025, Bryce Koon had also sent a message to the recipients listed above, with the same case caption and subject. That message reiterated the attachment of Plaintiff’s global settlement demand and again pointed to the Dropbox link for access. The body stated that this method would be the easiest for everyone involved and invited questions or discussion if needed. The same signature block for The Whaley Law Firm and the same confidentiality notice appeared at the end of this email as well.

Finally, on April 29, 2025, at 3:10:47 PM, Bryce Koon sent another email to Allie Wiles regarding the same case. He stated that he had spoken with his client about the deposition and that Thursdays appeared to be the best day for Mr. Ruhl’s availability. He proposed the date 06/05/25 and asked how that date sounded for everyone. The email included Koon’s standard firm signature with The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information and address, followed by the same confidentiality disclaimer noting that the message is intended only for the named recipient and advising recipients who received it in error to notify the sender and delete the message.

In sum, the record reflects three principal communications: (1) April 15, 2025, a demand letter and global settlement demand sent with a Dropbox link; (2) April 16, 2025, a response from Allie Orberson-Wiles indicating deposition scheduling is a prerequisite to formal responses; and (3) April 29, 2025, a scheduling note proposing a Thursday deposition and suggesting June 5, 2025 as a proposed deposition date. The communications repeatedly reference deposition scheduling for Timothy Ruhl in the case against Hoosier Cargo, with formal responses contingent upon timely deposition.

Case: Timothy-Ruhl-Premise-09-14-2023. Client: Timothy Ruhl. This file covers communications in the matter of Timothy Ruhl v. Hoosier Cargo, et al. (Jefferson 24-CI-005896).

In this sequence of emails, dated between mid-April and early May 2025, counsel discussed deposition scheduling and a global settlement demand. On April 15, 2025, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm (bryce@whaleylawfirm.com) sent a message to Charles Walker (cwalker@sonlegal.com) and Allison Wiles (aorberson-wiles@ppoalaw.com) regarding the Timothy Ruhl case. The email—sent with Timothy Ruhl’s Filevine project address included in the CC line as TimothyRuhlDOIZ4668241@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com—carried the subject Timothy Ruhl v. Hoosier Cargo, et al. (Jefferson 24-CI-005896). In the body, Bryce attached Plaintiff’s global settlement demand and provided a Dropbox link for access. The message was sent from The Whaley Law Firm’s office address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with the firm’s phone number 502-365-5043 and fax 502-237-3207. The email also carried the standard confidentiality/privilege disclaimer typical of correspondence from the firm. The recipients were Allie Orberson-Wiles and Charles Walker, with several others copied: tmarak@sonlegal.com, William Orberson (worberson@ppoalaw.com), Dawn Suter (dsuter@ppoalaw.com), Beth Alexander (balexander@ppoalaw.com), and Timothy Ruhl’s Filevine project email address.

On April 16, 2025 at 10:32?AM, Allison Wiles of Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC (aorberson-wiles@ppoalaw.com) replied to Bryce. She thanked Bryce for the demand but stated that the firm could not formally respond until they had Mr. Ruhl’s deposition. She asked Bryce to let her know when Mr. Ruhl would be available for his deposition and closed with an invitation to discuss questions by phone if needed. Allie Orberson-Wiles provided her direct line (502-560-9955) and office line (502-583-9900) and repeated the firm’s address at 716 West Main Street, Suite 300, Louisville, KY 40202. The response included the firm’s standard confidentiality disclaimer and privilege notice.

Earlier, on April 15, 2025 at 3:58 PM, Bryce Koon again wrote to the same recipients (Charles Walker, tmarak@sonlegal.com; William Orberson; and Allison Wiles) with Timothy Ruhl’s name in the subject line Timothy Ruhl v. Hoosier Cargo, et al. (Jefferson 24-CI-005896). In that message he attached Plaintiff’s global settlement demand and provided a Dropbox link for access. The CC line included Timothy Ruhl’s Filevine project email address as well. The email again echoed the confidentiality disclaimer customary to such communications, and it carried Bryce’s contact information at The Whaley Law Firm.

Finally, on April 29, 2025 at 3:10?PM, Bryce Koon sent Good afternoon counsel, stating that he had spoken with his client about deposition availability and noting that Thursdays seemed best for his client. He asked how 06/05/25 would work for everyone. Bryce again signed with The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details and included the standard confidentiality disclaimer in the thread.

On May 5, 2025, at 9:53:29 AM (GMT-04:00), Bryce followed up with a concise note: Good morning all, just wanted to circle back and see if this date worked for everyone. The May 5 message was sent from Bryce Koon, Esq., at The Whaley Law Firm, with the same Louisville address, phone, and fax, and it bore the same confidentiality disclaimer typical of the firm’s electronic communications. The To field for this latest message included Allison Wiles and Charles Walker, with Timothy Ruhl’s Filevine project email address again CC’d, along with tmarak, William Orberson, Dawn Suter, Beth Alexander, and Timothy Ruhl’s Filevine address.

In summary, the record shows a sequence of four key emails in mid-April to early May 2025: (1) April 15, 2025, Bryce Koon transmitted Plaintiff’s global settlement demand and provided a Dropbox link; (2) April 16, 2025, Allie Orberson-Wiles indicated that a deposition of Mr. Ruhl was a prerequisite to a formal response and asked for Mr. Ruhl’s availability; (3) April 29, 2025, Bryce proposed a deposition date window, noting Thursdays as preferable and asking if 06/05/25 would work; and (4) May 5, 2025, Bryce followed up to confirm whether the proposed date was workable for all parties. Throughout, multiple recipients and CCs were involved, and each email included the standard confidentiality and privilege notices.

Timothy Ruhl is the client in the matter Timothy Ruhl v. Hoosier Cargo, et al., Jefferson 24-CI-005896. The attached case notes compile a series of email exchanges between counsel regarding the plaintiff’s deposition scheduling and a settlement demand, spanning mid-April to early May 2025, with the principal participants being W. Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm and counsel for the defense at Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC.

On April 15, 2025, Bryce Koon, Esq., representing the plaintiff, sent an email to Charles Walker, tmarak, William Orberson, Allison Wiles, and others, including the Timothy Ruhl Filevine project email, with the subject Re: Timothy Ruhl v. Hoosier Cargo, et al. (Jefferson 24-CI-005896). In that message, he attached Plaintiff’s global settlement demand and noted that it would be the easiest method for everyone involved; he provided a Dropbox link for the documents and offered to discuss any questions.

The following day, April 16, 2025, Allison Orberson-Wiles of Phillips Parker Orberson & Arnett, PLC replied. She thanked Bryce for the demand and stated that PPOA could not formally respond until they have the deposition of Mr. Ruhl. She asked Bryce to inform them when Mr. Ruhl would be available for deposition and included her direct line (502-560-9943) and the firm’s contact details (716 West Main Street, Suite 300, Louisville, KY 40202; Office Phone 502-583-9900; Fax 502-587-1927).

Earlier, on April 29, 2025 at 3:10 PM, Bryce wrote to counsel again, indicating that he had spoken with his client about deposition availability and that Thursdays appeared to be the best day for Mr. Ruhl. He proposed 06/05/25 and asked how that date sounded for everyone. The message again included the firm’s standard confidentiality notice and Bryce’s contact information (The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Phone 502-365-5043; Fax 502-237-3207).

On May 5, 2025 at 9:53 AM, Bryce followed up with a further note to the same recipients, asking for confirmation that 06/05/25 would work for everyone and indicating that he was checking everyone’s availability.

On May 6, 2025 at 2:34 PM, Dawn Suter, a legal assistant for William B. Orberson and Allison Orberson-Wiles at PPOA, replied to Bryce. She advised that the proposed date (06/05/25) would not work for their office and asked if they could consider a later date. She included her direct line (502-560-9943) and PPOA’s main contact details (716 West Main Street, Suite 300, Louisville, KY 40202; Office Phone 502-583-9900; Fax 502-587-1927) and reiterated the confidentiality disclaimer typical of PPOA communications. She also noted that the message was intended for the named recipient and requested that if the message was received in error, Bryce contact the firm and destroy the copies.

That same day, at 3:15:03 PM GMT-04:00, Bryce Koon replied with a proposed alternative: “How about the following Thursday, 6/12?” He sent the response from The Whaley Law Firm with his standard firm signature and the accompanying confidentiality language.

Signatures and contact details appeared with each email. Bryce Koon’s signature identifies him as Esq. of The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with a phone number of 502-365-5043 and a fax number of 502-237-3207. The messages also consistently include the firm’s attorney-client privilege disclaimer. All communications reference the case caption and the Jefferson County docket number 24-CI-005896, and they repeatedly address scheduling Mr. Ruhl’s deposition and responding to the Plaintiff’s global settlement demand, including the Dropbox link provided in the April 15, 2025 email.

In summary, beginning with an April 15, 2025 email delivering the plaintiff’s global settlement demand, the parties engaged in a sequence of scheduling discussions about Mr. Ruhl’s deposition, with proposed dates of June 5 and June 12, 2025. PPOA’s Dawn Suter advised that June 5 would not work and requested a later date, and Bryce Koon subsequently proposed June 12, 2025 as an alternative. The communications maintained the standard confidentiality and privilege notices typical of the firms involved.
